item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: What’s Missing From the Syria Peace Talks
item.description: Why is a fledgling democracy in Syria being left out of talks about the country’s future?
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: SALEH M. MOHAMED

item.title: Op-Ed Columnist: The Islamic State of Molenbeek
item.description: A district of Brussels had in effect seceded from Belgium. Europe must fight an ideological battle against Wahhabi Islam.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: ROGER COHEN

item.title: Suicide Bombers Thwarted Outside Police Station in Southern Russia
item.description: One attacker was killed at a checkpoint near the city of Stavropol, and the second blew himself up, the Interior Ministry said.
item.dc:creator: NEIL MacFARQUHAR

item.title: A Brussels Mentor Who Taught ‘Gangster Islam’ to the Young and Angry
item.description: The network that Khalid Zerkani helped nurture in the district of Molenbeek has emerged as a central element in the Paris and Brussels attacks.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: ANDREW HIGGINS and KIMIKO DE FREYTAS-TAMURA
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.media:description: A street in Molenbeek, a district of Brussels that has often cropped up in terrorism investigations.

item.title: Colonel in North Korea’s Spy Agency Has Defected to South, Seoul Says
item.description: In a rare move, South Korea revealed Monday that the high-ranking military official had fled and confirmed that a diplomat abroad also defected in May.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN
item.media:description: Jeong Joon-hee of South Korea’s Unification Ministry announcing the defection of a North Korean officer on Monday. Opposition parties in the South have criticized the timing of the revelations before elections on Wednesday.

item.title: Kerry Visits Hiroshima Memorial and Underlines U.S.-Japan Alliance
item.description: Secretary of State John Kerry is the United States’ highest-ranking executive official to visit the site of one of the most destructive acts of World War II.
item.dc:creator: JONATHAN SOBLE
item.media:description: Secretary of State John Kerry, center left, with Japan’s foreign minister, Fumio Kishida, at Peace Memorial Park in Hiroshima on Monday.

item.title: Keiko Fujimori, Ex-President’s Daughter, Heads to Runoff in Peru
item.description: Keiko Fujimori, the daughter of a former authoritarian president, had about 38 percent of the vote, with a former prime minister trailing by double digits.
item.dc:creator: ANDREA ZARATE and NICHOLAS CASEY
item.media:description: Keiko Fujimori, the daughter Alberto Fujimori, of a former authoritarian president, was leading with about 38 percent of the vote on Sunday in Peru.

item.title: Revelation on Brussels Attackers Fuels Fears of New Assaults
item.description: News that militants in Belgium had planned to strike in France was a reminder that much is still unknown about the Islamic State’s networks in Europe.
item.dc:creator: ALISSA J. RUBIN and ERIC SCHMITT
item.media:description: Investigators continued to collect materials in Brussels on Saturday as part of their inquiry into the attacks in Paris and Brussels.

item.title: President of Chad Seeks Fifth Term in Election
item.description: Voters were deciding whether to re-elect Idriss Déby, who was favored to defeat 13 challengers.
item.dc:creator: REUTERS

item.title: Egypt Gives Saudi Arabia 2 Islands in a Show of Gratitude
item.description: The government of President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi returned two islands in the Red Sea to King Salman of Saudi Arabia in recognition of his support.
item.dc:creator: DECLAN WALSH
item.media:description: King Salman, the leader of Saudi Arabia, addressed the Egyptian parliament in Cairo during a five-day visit.

item.title: Behind Fake Degrees From Pakistan, a Maze of Deceit and a Case in Peril
item.description: Nearly a year after Axact, a software company, was accused of selling phony Internet diplomas, investigators have uncovered evidence of more fraud and the lead prosecutor has quit.
item.dc:creator: DECLAN WALSH
item.media:description: Shoaib Ahmed Shaikh, center, the chief executive of Axact, was escorted from a court appearance last May.

item.title: Arseniy Yatsenyuk, Ukraine’s Premier, Quits Amid Splits in Post-Revolution Alliance
item.description: Mr. Yatsenyuk, who came to power behind the Maidan street protests two years ago, announced he would step down.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.media:description: Arseniy P. Yatsenyuk last year. On Sunday, he signaled that he would attempt to smooth over cracks in Ukraine’s leadership after his resignation.

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Israel’s Unsung Protector: Obama
item.description: Of the last nine presidents, Obama is the only one who has completely shielded Israel from Security Council resolutions.
item.dc:creator: LARA FRIEDMAN
item.media:description: President Obama meeting with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel in the Oval Office in November.

item.title: David Cameron Releases Tax Data After Panama Papers Backlash
item.description: Mr. Cameron, the British prime minister, admitted that he had bungled his response to questions about his inheritance from his father, who had an offshore investment company.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER
item.media:description: Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain spoke at a Conservative Party gathering in London on Saturday, insisting he deserved the blame for mishandling the furor over his finances last week.

item.title: As Britain Contemplates Exit, Boris Johnson Prepares His Entrance
item.description: Mr. Johnson, the mayor of London, is bucking his party by supporting Britain’s exit from the European Union, effectively announcing his bid to be prime minister.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER
item.media:description: Mayor Boris Johnson of London is the highest-profile Tory to have defected from the campaign led by Prime Minister David Cameron to keep Britain inside the European Union.

item.title: Afghan General Plants Flowers in Helmand, but Taliban Lurk
item.description: Maj. Gen. M. Moein Faqir is the top military man in Helmand Province, more than half of which has been overrun by the Taliban in the past year.
item.dc:creator: ROD NORDLAND
item.media:credit: Adam Ferguson for The New York Times
item.media:description: Maj. Gen. M. Moein Faqir, the top Afghan military officer in Helmand Province, more than half of which has been overrun by Taliban in the past year.

item.title: Macedonian Police Use Tear Gas to Stop Migrants at Border
item.description: Hundreds of migrants who tried to break through a border fence in a northern Greek town were dispersed with tear gas and rubber bullets.
item.dc:creator: LIZ ALDERMAN
item.media:description: A migrant throwing a can of tear gas back toward Macedonian police officers in Idomeni, Greece, on Sunday.

item.title: Jakarta Journal: Gridlocked Jakarta Becomes Even Worse, at Least for a Week
item.description: The governor of Jakarta temporarily suspended its “three-in-one” car-pool system in part because it exploits children.
item.dc:creator: JOE COCHRANE
item.media:credit: Rony Zakaria for The New York Times
item.media:description: Traffic during afternoon rush hour in Jakarta, the capital of Indonesia, last week.

item.title: Powerful Earthquake Strikes Pakistan, India and Afghanistan
item.description: There were no immediate reports of widespread damage from the quake, which shook buildings and houses and caused panic in several cities.
item.dc:creator: SALMAN MASOOD
item.media:description: A woman in Srinagar, Kashmir, after a powerful earthquake on Sunday.

item.title: Fireworks Disaster at Kerala Temple Kills 106 in South India
item.description: A fireworks display during a religious festival set off a series of explosions, leveling buildings and injuring 383 people.
item.dc:creator: GEETA ANAND and SUHASINI RAJ
item.media:description: Debris at the site of several explosions at a temple in Kollam district, in the southern Indian state of Kerala, on Sunday. A medical officer said falling concrete pieces, as a result of the blasts, caused many of the deaths.
